lines.text: I've got the guts to die. What I want to know is, have you got the guts to live?
Thank you for keeping still, for backing me up in my lie.
Maggie, we're through with lies and liars in this house. Lock the door.
Why is Uncle Brick on the floor?
Because I tried to kill your Aunt Maggie. But I failed. And I fell.
There ain't nothin' more powerful than the odor of mendacity!
What is the victory of a cat on a hot tin roof?
Just staying on it I guess, long as she can.

This was what my father left me, this lousy old suitcase! And on the inside was nothing, nothing but his uniform from the Spanish-American war. That was his legacy to me! Nothing at all! And I built this place from nothing.
That was all he left you?

He was a hobo, the best-known tramp on the boxcar circuit. He'd worked once in awhile as a field hand, and I'd tag along. Sat on my bare bottom in the dirt, waiting for him. Outside of hunger, the first thing I remember is shame. I was ashamed of that miserable old tramp. I was riding boxcars with him when I was nine, something you never had to do. You'll never have to bury me the way I buried him. I buried him in a meadow alongside a railroad track. He was running to catch a freight and his heart give out. You know something? That old tramp died laughing.
Laughing at what?
Himself, I guess. Old hobo tramp, not a nickel to his name, no future, no past.
Maybe he was laughing because he was happy. Happy at having you with him. He took you everywhere. He kept you with him.
I don't want to talk about that.
[pause]
Yeah, I loved him. I reckon I never loved anything as much as that lousy old tramp.
And you say he left you nothing but a suitcase with a uniform in it?
And some memories.
And love.
Maggie the cat is alive. I'm alive.
Look, Mama, he's wearing Brick's birthday present. I haven't given you my present yet, but I will now. I have an announcement to make.
What kind of an announcement?
An announcement of life beginning. A child is coming, sired by Brick out of Maggie the cat. I have Brick's child in my body, and that is my present to you.
Did you ever in all your born days hear such a bold-faced lie?
Shut up.

[kissing Maggie]
Thank you. Thank you very much.
Yes indeed, this girl has life in her body. And that's no lie. Gooper, I want to talk to my lawyer in the morning. Brick?
Yes, Big Daddy?
I'm going to go out and look this place over before I give it up. The place and the people on it.
A family crisis brings out the best and the worst in every member of the family.
That's the truth.
Amen.
You want to talk about the truth? You're not pregnant!
Keep still, Mae.
She's making it up!
I said shut up.
Don't you try to kid us, Maggie!
Mae, she's not kidding you.
How can she be pregnant by you when you won't even...
Mae, will you be quiet!
We occupy the next room and the walls between aren't soundproof. We hear the nightly pleadings and the nightly refusals!
Not everybody makes as much noise about love as you do.
Brick, I never thought you would stoop to her level!
You heard what Big Daddy said. That girl's got life in her body.
That's a lie!
What's that smell in this room? Didn't you notice it, Brick? Didn't you notice a powerful and obnoxious odor of mendacity in this room?

[Offering Big Daddy morphine]
It'll kill the pain, that's all.

[Wincing with pain]
It'll kill the senses too! You... you got pain - at least you know you're alive.
[groans]
I don't know.
We can start by helping each other up this stairs.
But, how in hell on earth can you imagine you're gonna have a child with a man who cannot stand you.
Careful Maggie, your claws are showing.
The point is I won't see this place run into the ground by a drunken ex-football hero.
You shut up about my husband!
You shut up!
Sometimes I wish I had a pill to make people disappear.
Why did you and Brick suddenly decide to drive up from New Orleans?
For your birthday, what else?
I had a birthday last year and the year before that. Didn't see you then.
Well, you know how Brick is sometimes.
Maybe he thought he'd be coming to my funeral, instead of my birthday.
But Brick loves you! He does!
But does he love you?
What do you want, proof?
If I was married to you three years, you'd have the living proof. You'd have three kids already and a fourth in the oven.
This is a deliberate campaign to ruin Brick!
He don't need no help.

[crying]
And for the most sordid reasons on earth! Greed! Avarice and greed!
Margaret, darling, don't cry.
Well, that takes the cake! Who are the tears for? Brick? Big Daddy? Or are they for yourself? Are you crying cause you're childless? You know why she's got no kids? Ask her big, beautiful husband!
Mae!
So you bought me a birthday present, huh?
No sir, Maggie bought it.
She's got good taste, that girl.
In some things, yes, but not in men.
I'm talking in Big Daddy's languge now. I'm his wife, not his widow. I'm still his wif!
What we've got here...
What Gooper's saying is just a plan, a basis.
I'll tell you what your plan is. Margaret, what is it Big Daddy always says when he's disgusted?
He says bull when he's disgusted.
Yes, that's right. I say bull too, like Big Daddy.
Well, coarse language don't seem called for to me.
Bull!
You can be young without money, but you can't be old without it.

[to Big Mama]
Gooper is your first born. Why he always had to carry a bigger load of the resposibilities than Brick? Brick never carried a thing in his life but a football or a high ball.
Don't make a fool of yourself, Maggie.
I don't mind making a fool of myself over you.
Well, I mind. I feel embarrassed for you.
Feel embarrassed? Well, I can't live on this way.
You agreed to accept that condition.
I know I did. But I can't! I can't!
I'm ashamed, Big Daddy. That's why I'm a drunk. When I'm drunk, I can stand myself.
But it's always there in the mornin', ain't it? The truth and it's here right now!
[They run outside into the rain]
You're just feeling sorry for yourself; that's all it is! Self-pity!
[Inside the carport]

You didn't kill Skipper. He killed himself. You and Skipper and millions like you are living in a kids' world. Playing games, touchdowns, no worries, no responsibilities. Life ain't no damn football game. Life ain't just a buncha high spots.
[He grabs Brick]

You're a thirty-year-old kid. Soon you'll be a fifty-year-old kid. Pretendin' you're hearin' cheers when there ain't any. Dreamin' and drinkin' your life away. Heroes in the real world live twenty-four hours a day, not just two hours in a game. Mendacity! You won't...
[winces in obvious pain]

You won't live with mendacity? Well, you're an expert at it! The truth is pain and sweat and payin' bills and makin' love to a woman that you don't love any more. Truth is dreams that don't come true, and nobody prints your name in the paper 'til you die.
I don't give a damn whether Big Daddy likes me, or don't likes me. Or did or never did. Or will or will never.
People like doing what they used to do, after they've stopped being able to do it.
Why'd you let Mama buy all this stuff?

The human animal is a beast that must die. If he's got money, he buys and buys and buys everything he can, in the crazy hope one of those things will be life-everlasting, which it can never be. I've suddenly noticed you don't call me Big Daddy anymore. If you needed a big daddy, why didn't you come to me? If you needed someone to lean on, why Skipper? Why not me? I'm your father! Why didn't you come to your kinfolk, the people that love you?
You don't know what love means! To you, it's just another four-letter word.
You've got a mighty short memory! What was there you ever wanted that I didn't buy?
You can't buy love!
Who do you think I bought it for? It's yours! The place, the money, everything's yours!
I don't want things!
Stop that, ya little no-neck monster!
You know what I feel like? I feel all the time like a cat on a hot tin roof.
Then jump off the roof, Maggie. Jump off it. Cats jump off roofs and land uninjured. Do it. Jump.
Jump where? Into what?
When marriage goes on the rocks, the rocks are there.
[pats the bed]
Right there.
[pats the bed again for emphasis]

[to Maggie]
Why don't you go up there and drink with Brick if the conquerin' hero hasn't passed out already? He may have to pass up the Sugar Bowl this year or was it the Rose Bowl he made his famous run in?
It was the punch bowl, Honey, the cut-glass punch bowl.
You've got to.
I don't have to do anything I don't want to! Now, you keep forgetting the conditions on which I agreed to stay on living with you.
I'm not living with you! We occupy the same cage, that's all.
I'm gonna pick me a choice woman and I'm gonna smother her in minks and choke her with diamonds. Boy, I'm gonna be happy.

Wouldja look at all this stuff? Bought most of it when I took your mother to Europe on that Cook's Tour. Never had such a lousy time in my life. I tell you that Europe ain't nothin' but a wore-out auction, just a great big fire sale, the whole rotten thing. Boy, Big Mama just wild in it, and she just bought and bought and bought. Sure is lucky I'm a rich man, yes, sirree, sure is lucky. Got any idea how much I'm worth, son? Ask Gooper. He knows. He knows to the penny 'less I missed my guess. Close on ten million dollars in cash and blue chip stocks besides twenty-eight thousand of the richest acres this side of the Valley Nile.
Well, that is pretty rich to be.
But, there's one thing you can't buy at any European fire sale,
[clears cobwebs from broken clock]
or any other market on Earth. That's your life. You can't buy back your life when it's finished.
No, sir, no-one can.
Feelin' sorry for me, or for you?
For you, Papa.
That's good, 'cause you're gonna miss me, boy.

We've still got one thing on our side. No, two things. Are my seams straight? Big Daddy dotes on you, Brick. He can't stand Brother Man and Brother Man's wife. That fertility monster, she's downright odious to him, I can tell. That's the second thing we've got on our side. He likes me. The way he looks me up and down and over, he's still got an eye for girls.
That kind of talk is disgusting.
Did anybody ever tell you you're a back-aching Puritan, Brick? I think it's a fine thing that a man on the doorstep of death can still look at a woman like me with what I call deserved appreciation.
Let's go home.
Don't you want to ride with the children, honey?
No!

[laughing]
He's his sassy old self again, all right!
Be quiet, woman!
We never were a very happy family. There just wasn't much joy in this house. It wasn't Big Daddy's fault. It was just... you know how some families are happy.
Grown-ups don't hang up on their friends! And they don't hang up on their wives and they don't hang up on life! That's the truth and that's what you can't face!
Can you face the truth?
Try me.
Sure, somebody else's truth.
So you're running again?
Yeah, I am! Running from lies like birthday congratulations and many happy returns when there won't be any!
[pause]
What did you say?
Forget it.
Won't be any happy returns?
Please just let me go home. Leave the place to Goober and Mae.
Leave the place? Who said I was gonna leave the place? I'll outlive you! I'll bury you!

You said I never loved Big Daddy. How would you know? How would he know? Did he ever let anybody love him? It was always Brick, always. From the day he was born, he was always partial to Brick. Why? Big Daddy wanted me to become a lawyer. I became a lawyer. He said to get married, I got married. He said to have kids, I had kids. He said to live in Memphis, I lived in Memphis. Whatever he said to do, I did.
Did the storm cause any damage, Big Daddy?
Which storm you talking about, the one on the outside or the hullabaloo I heard going on in here? Heard some mighty loud talking. What's the powwow about?
Nothing, Big Daddy, nothing at all.
What's in them important-looking documents you got there, Gooper?
Nothing, sir, nothing much of anything at all.
Big Daddy, Big Daddy. Now, what makes him so big? His big heart, his big belly, or his big money?

[to Mae]
Not only will I spit on you, I'll claw your eyes out.
Do you make Brick happy?
Why don't you ask if he makes me happy?
Where did I fail you? Where did I make my mistake?
What's all this about?
Doc, Big Mama wants the whole truth about the report we got from the clinic today.
The truth, the truth! Everybody keeps hollering about the truth. Well, the truth is as dirty as lies!
Is there something I don't know, Doc?
Well, Ida...
I want to know! Somebody must be lying! I want to know about my husand!
He had the most thorough examination ever given at the Oppenheim clinic.
It's one of the best in the country.
It's the best in the country, bar none.
They were ninety-nine percent sure before they even started.
Sure of what?
Not now!
The test was positive!
Mae, shut up.
It's helpless, Ida. He knows it, too.
You're a drinker and i'm childless.
I don't like locked doors in my house.
Gooper?
[calling his name inquisitively]
What have all the chil'ens been shot for?
Everything 'cept shootin' chickens, I guess.
